list_definition.definition: to make a sharp noise by hitting or tapping, especially on a door etc to attract attention

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Just then, someone knocked at the door.

list_definition.definition: to cause to move, especially to fall, by hitting (often accidentally)

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She knocked a vase on to the floor while she was dusting.

list_definition.definition: to put into a certain state or position by hitting

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He knocked the other man senseless.

list_definition.definition: (often with against, on) to strike against or bump into

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She knocked against the table and spilt his cup of coffee
I knocked my head on the car door.

list_definition.definition: an act of knocking or striking

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: She gave two knocks on the door
He had a nasty bruise from a knock he had received playing football.

list_definition.definition: the sound made by a knock, especially on a door etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Suddenly they heard a loud knock.

list_ex_of_english: And young audiences found the slapstick and knock-about violence appealing.
Imagine that one person knocks on the door and steps into another's office.
He actually went down to see them and knocked on doors.
The most commonly produced transitive verbs were knock and do (mostly present progressives and past tense uses).
Heterozygous knock-out mice for brain-derived neurotrophic factor show a pathway-specific impairment of long-term potentiation but normal critical period for monocular deprivation.
However, in the knock-on source calculation, the thermal motion of background fuel ions was neglected.
The man found himself stuck on the roof because he knocked down the ladder.
The other thing he said to me was that you don't knock something when it is working.
